title: Ticket #7732: Metrics to measure avoidance of repeated drains.
description:
Added the following attribute to the machine ad to implement the corresponding metrics:

  • LastDrainStopTime, which records when the last (unix epoch) time when draining stopped (was cancelled), as distinct from the last time draining completed.

Added the following attributes to the defrag daemon's ad:

  • RecentDrainsList, which is a list of ClassAds describing the 10 most-recent drain commands sent by the defrag daemon; and
    • when -- the Unix epoch time the command was issued,
    • who -- the name of the slot being drained, and
    • what -- one of "graceful", "quick", or "fast".
  • RecentCancelsList, which is a list of ClassAds describing the 10 most-recent drains cancel commands sent by the defrag daemon.
    • when -- the Unix epoch time the command was issue,
    • who -- the name of the slot whose drain is being cancelled.

Added the recent_counter_timer stats "Drain" to the machine ad, resulting in the usual set of attributes, list below.

  • RecentResMgrDrain
  • RecentResMgrDrainRuntime
  • ResMgrDrain
  • ResMgrDrainRuntime

These attributes may be read from a startd in the usual ways, including 

condor_status -l -statistics ALL:2 -direct <slot-name>

original ticket body

Context: the CHTC uses the default DEFRAG_RANK, which is -ExpectedMachineGracefulDrainingBadput. If a machine has no jobs, and doesn't get any (because it's been dedicated to a user who's idle right now), it will repeatedly sort to the top of the DEFRAG_RANK. It would not normally be drained more than once, but the CHTC has DEFGRAG_WHOLE_MACHINE_EXPR constructed in such a way that this machine is never considered "whole."

Before we can talk about solving the problem, we need to define (and implement as necessary) some metrics so we can know what success means.

We came up three simple metrics during our discussion:

(a) Add an explicit attribute in the machine ad for when a startd most recently finished draining. (We have EnteredCurrentState, but that's super-obscure.) To match EnteredCurrentState, this should include cancellations.

(b) Add an attribute to the machine ad, perhaps using the "stats" implementation, for number of "recent" drains.

(c) The defrag daemon should record and advertise the last ?? draining commands it issued, specifically when and to whom.

Recording draining metrics in both the defrag daemon and the startd allow us to account for manually-issued drain commands. We don't know right now if the difference between a daemon- and admin- issued drain will be important, so don't distinguish in (a) for now.

It would be nice to know, to see if we're draining efficiently, if the job(s) which ran on the just-drained machines would not have run without the draining. This seems like a rather complicated (and configuration-specific) question to answer directly in one of the daemons, so think about what would be required and how to gather it.

EnteredCurrentState only changes after a drain without auto-resume is cancelled, not when it completes. We can have LastDrainStopTime report when the drain actually stopped (possibly even preserving it against the drain being cancelled), if we feel that would be more useful.

2020-Jul-22 16:01:19 by tlmiller:
I'm making RecentDrainsList and RecentCancelsList reverse-chronological, so that the most recent drain or cancel is always index 0.
